You have a single instance of a MongoDB server (127.0.0.1) that is currently running on port 27017. You want to distribute the data from your database across multiple data centers to mitigate the problem of unavailability of data when the server goes down. For this, you want to run another instance of MongoDB named 'ServerB' (127.0.0.1:27018) by configuring port 27018 using the sharding technique.

You need to perform the following operations:
1. Create a separate database named 'configdb' in the data folder that is located in MongoDB installation folder.
2. Start Server B in configuration mode. 
3. Start the mongos instance by specifying Server B as the configuration server.
4. Connect server B with default MongoDB server instance using the MongoDB Shell.

Which of the following set of commands will perform the above operations without causing any errors?

Options

1.

> mkdir /data/myconfigdb
> mongos -start ServerB –configdb: 27018
> mongos -start ServerB –configdb: 27018
> mongo -connecthost ServerB –port 27017

2.

> mkdir /data/myconfigdb
> mongod –configdb ServerB: 27018
> mongos –configdb ServerB: 27018
> mongo –host ServerB –port 27017

3.

> mkdir /data/myconfigdb
> mongod -n –configdb ServerB: 27018
> mongos -c –configdb ServerB: 27018
> mongo –rplSet ServerB –port 27017

4.

> mkdir /data/myconfigdb
> mongod --db configdb ServerB: 27018
> mongos --db configdb ServerB: 27018
> mongo –ins ServerB –port: 27017

You are dealing with an application having a large database named 'microblogs'. Given below is a sample document from the collection 'blogusers'. 
Document:
{ "_id" : ObjectId("60cb59a41c3423c6cd1188cb"), "blog_id" : "5432",  "author" : "Eric Stokes",  "title" : "Environment protection"}

For maintaining the efficiency of the database, you need to distribute the load of the server among the instances of a server using the sharding technique. Considering 'title' as a shared key, you need to perform range-based sharding on a collection 'blogusers' using the shard key.

Which of the following will perform the given operation successfully?

You have a collection 'employees' in a database 'mycompany'. You have created one replica of the MongoDB server (127.0.0.1:27017) and connected it to the server. To ensure the high viability of the data, you want to set up one more shard- ServerC (127.0.0.1:27019) and shard the database 'mycompany'.
First of all, you need to connect to the mongo server and add a new instance ServerC (127.0.0.1:27019) to the existing MongoDB cluster. Secondly, shard the database 'mycompany' and the collection using the shard keys 'employee_id' and 'employee_name'.

Which of the following queries will perform best in the above scenario?

Queries

1.

> mongo --host --port 27017
> sh.addShard("ServerC:27019")
> sh.enableSharding(mycompany)
> sh.shardCollection("db.employees", {"employee_id":1, "employee_name":1})

2.

> mongo --host --port 27017
> sh.ShardServer("ServerC:27019")
> sh.sharddatabase(mycompany)
> sh.shardCollection("db.employees", {$shardkey:{"employee_id":1, "employee_name":1}})

3.

> mongo --host --port 27017
> sh.ShardCluster("ServerC:27019")
> sh.addShard(mycompany)
> sh.shardCollection("db.employees").shardKey({"employee_id":1 , "employee_name":1})

4.

> mongo --host --port 27017
> sh.shard("ServerC:27019")
> sh.enableShardingOn(mycompany)
> sh.shardCollection("db.employees").shardMany({"employee_id":1, "employee_name":1})
In NoSQL, which type of sharding is supported?
